text: [Preface to the Book] Indeed, the science of Jarh and Ta'dil (Discrediting and Accrediting narrators) is among the most noble of sciences and the greatest in value, for by it, authentic Hadiths are distinguished from weak ones, and accepted reports from rejected ones. There is no jurist (Faqih) who is not in need of it, and no Hadith scholar (Muhaddith) who does not resort to it and seek guidance from it. Jarh and Ta'dil is the scale by which the men of Hadith are weighed, and through which the narrator whose Hadith is accepted is known from the one whose Hadith is rejected. The scholars of Prophetic Hadith gave great attention to the science of Jarh and Ta'dil, to the point that the noble Companion Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) said: "Indeed, this knowledge is religion, so look to whom you take your religion from." The science of Jarh and Ta'dil is not claimed by just any person or even every Muhaddith, for conditions must be met in the critic (Al-Jarih) and the accreditor (Al-Mu'addil). Criticism and accreditation are not accepted except from a vigilant, upright person who knows the reasons for discrediting, nor is validation accepted except from one who knows its reasons. The brilliant critics among the Imams and Huffaz (Memorizers) took the lead in this science, such as Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal, Al-Bukhari, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Ma'in, and Ibn Al-Madini. Among them is the Imam and Hafiz Al-Daraqutni. There is no wonder in that, for he was the unique figure of his era, the peerless one of his time, and the Imam of his age. The knowledge of Hadith, the knowledge of its defects ('Ilal), and the names and conditions of its narrators ended with him, along with truthfulness, trustworthiness, jurisprudence, acumen, correct creed, and soundness of school (Madhhab).

text: These are the questions of Abu Bakr Al-Barqani to the Imam of his time, Abu Al-Hasan Al-Daraqutni, regarding Jarh and Ta'dil... My Generous Lord has guided me to investigate and study them. The "Questions of Al-Barqani" is considered one of the very important books in the field of Jarh and Ta'dil, especially since it involves two great Imams famous for Jarh and Ta'dil and the knowledge of men and Hadith defects. Publishing these questions renders a great service to the library of Hadith and the purified Prophetic Sunnah, especially since it completes the series of questions on Jarh and Ta'dil that were posed to Imam Al-Daraqutni. Professor Muwaffaq bin Abdullah bin Abdul Qadir has published (Questions of Al-Hakim to Al-Daraqutni) and (Questions of Hamza Al-Sahmi to Al-Daraqutni). Here we are bringing forth (Questions of Al-Barqani to Al-Daraqutni), and God willing, (Questions of Abu Abdul Rahman Al-Sulami to Al-Daraqutni) is on the way. And success is only from the Lord of the Worlds.

text: Study of the Questions (Su'alat). 1 - General Definition of Su'alat: 'Su'alat' refers to a student asking his Sheikh about men of Hadith, or defects in a text, etc. The Questions of Abu Bakr Al-Barqani to Al-Daraqutni are considered one link in a chain of multiple links. A number of Al-Daraqutni's students from among the senior Huffaz asked him about the defects of Hadith and its men, and he gave his judgment on them regarding discrediting (Jarh) and accrediting (Ta'dil). There is no wonder in that, for we have seen those who praised him saying: (The Hafiz of his era, the unique one of his time; no one like him came after Al-Nasa'i), along with other expressions of praise and commendation said about him. For this reason, a number of senior Huffaz and Muhaddithin turned to Imam Al-Daraqutni asking him about Hadith defects and the knowledge of men. Among these Huffaz were: 1 - Abu Al-Qasim Hamza bin Yusuf Al-Sahmi (Died 427 AH), author of the History of Jurjan, who asked Al-Daraqutni about Hadith defects and Jarh and Ta'dil. Most of those he asked about were actually Al-Daraqutni's own teachers or the teachers of his teachers, so Al-Daraqutni gave his judgment on them. It is worth noting that Professor Muwaffaq bin Abdullah brought these questions to light in a verified and accurately indexed edition. 2 - Questions of Abu Abdullah Al-Hussein bin Ahmad, regarding people whom Al-Bukhari and Muslim included in their Sahihs, but whom Al-Nasa'i weakened in the Book of Weak Narrators.

The Questions of Abu Bakr Al-Barqani are but one link in a series of multiple links in which Imam Al-Daraqutni brought forth for us his opinions and thoughts on Jarh and Ta'dil and Hadith defects. Most of the questions begin with: "I said to Abu Al-Hasan," sometimes: "I heard Abu Al-Hasan," other times: "And I heard Abu Al-Hasan," and rarely: "And Abu Al-Hasan said." Al-Daraqutni's style of criticism in Al-Barqani's questions is the same as his style in the questions of Al-Sahmi and Al-Hakim. Sometimes it is a complete criticism, where he judges the narrator with Jarh or Ta'dil generally, such as saying for example: (Weak - Da'if), or (Abandoned - Matruk)... etc. And sometimes the criticism is of a restricted type, where he judges the narrator with accreditation (Ta'dil) while criticizing him in a specific aspect.

text: Sometimes the criticism is regarding the text (Matn), and this criticism stems from his knowledge of an obscure, hidden cause that flaws the Hadith, and we will see some of that in this book of ours. There is no surprise in Imam Al-Daraqutni pointing out the defects of texts, for he is the expert in that, whose book on 'Ilal (Defects) was described as one of the best books on Hadith defects. By joining this book with the rest of the questions directed to Imam Al-Daraqutni, we attempt to assemble the series he left us of his criticism of men and his discussion on Hadith defects. And Allah is the Granter of success to what is right. [Biography of Imam Al-Daraqutni] (1) His Lineage and Upbringing: He is the proficient Imam and Hafiz, Abu Al-Hasan, Ali bin Umar bin Ahmad bin Mahdi bin Masud bin Al-Nu'man Al-Baghdadi, from the people of the Dar Al-Qutn district in Baghdad, to which he is attributed. He was born in the year 306 AH. From his youth, he began seeking knowledge from the great scholars of his time. He said about himself: "I wrote [Hadith] in the beginning of the year 315." He studied Shafi'i jurisprudence under Abu Sa'id Al-Istakhri, and attended the gathering of Al-Baghawi regularly. After hearing from the Sheikhs of his homeland, he began traveling to other countries, journeying to most regions famous for the high status of Hadith science within them. Among the interesting anecdotes in this regard is that his family and clan hoped for him to be the town's Quran reciter. They used to say: "Al-Kattani - one of Al-Daraqutni's peers in his town - will emerge as the town's Muhaddith, and Al-Daraqutni will emerge as the town's reciter." Al-Daraqutni says: "So I emerged as a Muhaddith, and Al-Kattani as a reciter." Thus, the scholar Al-Daraqutni had a good scientific upbringing which qualified him to be one of the Sheikhs of Islam. (2) Al-Daraqutni's Sheikhs from whom he received knowledge: One cannot enumerate the scholars from whom he received knowledge because that would require a separate book, but I will mention some of these scholars to clarify the intensity of Imam Al-Daraqutni's pursuit of knowledge.

text:
[Biography of Imam al-Dāraqutnī]

(1) His lineage and upbringing:
He is the precise preserving imam, Abū al-Hasan ʿAlī ibn ʿUmar ibn Aḥmad ibn Mahdī ibn Masʿūd ibn al-Nuʿmān al-Baghdādī, from the district of Dār al-Qaṭan in Baghdad, and he is attributed to it.
He was born in the year 306 AH. From his early youth, he began seeking knowledge from the senior scholars of his time. He said about himself: “I wrote (hadith) in the beginning of the year 315 AH.”
He studied Shāfiʿī jurisprudence under Abū Saʿīd al-Isṭakhrī, and he would attend the study circle of al-Baghawī regularly.
After listening to the scholars of his homeland, he began traveling to different lands, journeying to most of the regions famous for their high standing in the science of hadith.

Among the interesting things mentioned here is that his family and relatives hoped he would become the town’s Qur’an reciter. They would say: “Al-Kattānī — one of al-Dāraqutnī’s peers in his town — will become the town’s hadith scholar, and al-Dāraqutnī will become the town’s reciter.”
Al-Dāraqutnī said: “I ended up becoming the hadith scholar, and al-Kattānī became the reciter.”

Thus the scholars raised al-Dāraqutnī with a strong scholarly upbringing that qualified him to be among the great teachers of Islam.

(2) The teachers from whom al-Dāraqutnī learned:
It is not possible for one to enumerate all the scholars from whom he learned, as that would require a separate work. But I will mention some of these scholars so that a clear picture appears of the intensity of Imam al-Dāraqutnī’s pursuit of knowledge.

text: He said: It is not authentic. 49 - I said: Its chain is Hasan (good), a group narrated it from Al-Fadl? He said: Yes, by Allah, it is Hasan, except that it has a defect (Illah). Waki' (1) narrated it from Abdullah
foot_note:
1. = Al-Tirmidhi said: In the chapter there is a report from Anas and Aisha. [Meaning and Benefits of Hadith]: His saying: (He used to glance in prayer): meaning looking with the outer corner of his eyes, and 'Lihaz' is looking with the edge of the eye next to the temple. His saying: (Right and left): meaning sometimes to the right side, and sometimes to the left side. His saying: (And he did not twist his neck): meaning he did not turn or incline his neck. His saying: (Behind his back): meaning to his direction (behind him). Al-Tibi said: 'Layy' is twisting a rope... and he twisted his head meaning inclined it. Perhaps this turning was in voluntary prayer for it is easier, as in the Hadith of Anas. Ibn Abd al-Malik said: It is said his turning, peace be upon him, once or a few times was to show that it does not invalidate prayer, or it was for something necessary. If one twists his neck behind his back, meaning turns his chest away from the Qiblah, it invalidates the prayer. Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: Several Hadiths were reported regarding the dislike of turning explicitly, not meeting Al-Bukhari's conditions, including what is in Ahmad and Ibn Khuzaymah from the Hadith of Abu Dharr raised (Marfu'): (Allah continues to face the servant in his prayer as long as he does not turn; if he turns his face away, He turns away from him). And from the Hadith of Al-Harith Al-Ash'ari similarly, adding (So if you pray do not turn). The first was also narrated by Abu Dawud and Al-Nasa'i. The intended turning mentioned is as long as he does not turn his back to the Qiblah with his chest or his entire neck. The reason for the dislike of turning is possibly due to lack of khushu' (humility), or leaving the facing of the Qiblah with part of the body. See: Tuhfat Al-Ahwadhi (3 / 195 - 196), Fath Al-Bari (2 / 234).
